[a polite greeting or farewell used when meeting or parting] hello; goodbye; good morning; good afternoon; good evening; good night; greetings
[spoken formally to a person of higher rank or status, e.g. parents, teachers] "Thank you" [male: add ครับ ; female: add ค่ะ ]
"It doesn't matter." — "Never mind." — "You're welcome" — "Don't mention it." — "It's no big deal."
"See you later." — "See you soon!" — "Until we meet again."
to be feeling fine; I am fine; I'm fine.
[spoken politely by a male] hello; goodbye
[spoken politely by a female] hello or goodbye
"How's it going?" — "How do you feel?" — "How do you do?" — "What's up?"
anything will do; that option would also be fine; whatever; anything will be okay; anything you want
[a person, younger and/or lower in status, thanking the other who is older and/or higher in status] "Thank you very much"
[spoken by a male] "Please make the food spicy-hot"
"I don't think so" — "not right" — "not so" — "not true" — "No, it is not"
"Are you a man or a woman?"
textBeforeTable: H/—since he doesn't know who may be listening, he endeavors to be most polite. F khrap H/ to make your questions more polite). If you listen to broadcast talk shows in Thailand, you may hear a speaker ending every single sentence with /na คะ   /kha F/ น่ะ  /na F (ladies, remember to use H or kha F/ before you say khrap น่ะ  /na At first, Westerners find these particles easy to forget, but with practice, eventually you will find yourself adding polite particles automatically. You can further "soften" requests or aggresive statements by also adding F/ can be used by children or between intimate friends. There are many more particles in common use, especially considering regional variations; some Thai people will stick with an obscure favorite as a matter of personality. จ้ะ  /ja H/ to the end of questions. คะ   /kha F/ to the end of statements and ค่ะ   /kha H/ while women should add ครับ   /khrap particle to the end. Male speakers should add A Brief Note on Polite Particles Most of these phrases can (and should) be made more polite by adding
